keywords: Benthic macroinvertebrates, sampling method, lab processing method, biological integrity, stream health

abstract:
This text describes a method for evaluating the health of streams and rivers by analyzing the community of benthic macroinvertebrates, which are animals that live on the river bottom. The importance of benthic macroinvertebrates lies in their role as indicators of watershed health, as they are sensitive to changes in water quality and habitat conditions.

The text outlines a specific protocol for collecting and processing these organisms, including details about the sampling method (ID 244) and laboratory processing method (ID 164). This procedure is designed to generate data that can be used to assess the overall health of a stream reach, providing valuable information on the presence and abundance of different macroinvertebrate species.

The use of this protocol has several advantages. By employing standardized methods for benthic macroinvertebrate assessment, researchers can compare their results with those from other studies, facilitating collaboration and data sharing. Additionally, the use of multi-metric approaches, such as the Index of Biotic Integrity (IBI) or predictive models like River InVertebratePrediction and Classification System (RIVPACS), enables researchers to analyze their findings in a consistent and quantitative manner, helping to identify trends and patterns related to water quality and habitat conditions.

It is important to note that this method focuses on evaluating the overall health of a stream reach, rather than individual habitats or providing data for analyzing macroinvertebrates as a food source for fish. However, it is highly recommended that other relevant environmental data be collected in conjunction with benthic macroinvertebrate sampling to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the aquatic ecosystem.

In summary, this method provides a standardized and effective approach for assessing stream health by analyzing the community of benthic macroinvertebrates. The use of this protocol allows researchers to compare their findings with those from other studies, employing consistent methods for data analysis and sharing valuable information on water quality and habitat conditions.

description:
The text body provides information about the collection and analysis of benthic macroinvertebrates for evaluating stream health and biological integrity. These organisms, which inhabit the bottom of streams and rivers (benthos), are characterized by their large size and lack of a backbone (macroinvertebrate). The text describes two specific methods: sampling method ID 244 and lab processing method ID 164, designed to generate data for characterizing benthic macroinvertebrate assemblages and assessing human-caused disturbances.

The purpose of this protocol is to assess the macroinvertebrate community within a specific stream reach as an indicator of biological integrity and overall stream health. The methods are not intended for evaluating individual stream habitats or providing data on macroinvertebrates as a food source for fish. However, it is highly recommended to collect additional physical habitat, biological, and water quality data at each site.

The described collection procedures involve taking samples from the bottom of streams and rivers using specific techniques, such as kick net, dipping, or surber sampling methods. Once collected, macroinvertebrates are preserved in a suitable solution (formalin or alcohol) for lab processing according to method ID 164. This process includes identifying, sorting, and enumerating the collected organisms under a microscope.

Macroinvertebrates play a significant role as indicators of watershed health due to their unique characteristics: they spend most of their life in water, are relatively easy to collect, exhibit varying tolerance levels to pollution and habitat alteration, can be identified in a laboratory setting, have limited mobility, and serve as integrators of environmental conditions.

To analyze the collected biotic data, multi-metric approaches like Index of Biotic Integrity (IBI) or predictive models such as River InVertebrate Prediction and Classification System (RIVPACS) can be used. These methods allow for sharing standardized data among different users and direct comparison of results. It is important to note that the described sampling procedures do not exclude the use of other, project-specific sampling techniques.

target: Characterizing benthic macroinvertebrate assemblages for stream health assessment.

constraints:

2. It is highly recommended that other physical habitat, biological and/or water quality data also be collected at any given site. (Line 15)
3. The procedures described will allow analysis of biotic data with multi-metric methods or predictive models, but do not preclude the use of other sampling procedures for specific project objectives. (Lines 20-23)

These constraints are in place to ensure that the macroinvertebrate sampling method is used appropriately and in conjunction with other necessary data collections to accurately assess stream health and biological integrity. Additionally, the method is designed to be standardized for data comparison and sharing purposes.
